abstract.p: Washington Mystics defeat New York Liberty, 57-56; photo (M)

block.p: Chamique Holdsclaw peered through the four Liberty hands flying desperately in her face, and from 10 feet back, she floated her trademark fade-away jumper.

As Holdsclaw fell backward to the floor at Madison Square Garden, her shot pierced the net to give the Mystics a 57-56 lead, stunning the Liberty with only 10.8 seconds left in what had already been a gritty tug-of-war between the Women's National Basketball Association rivals.
Chamique Holdsclaw peered through the four Liberty hands flying desperately in her face, and from 10 feet back, she floated her trademark fade-away jumper.

As Holdsclaw fell backward to the floor at Madison Square Garden, her shot pierced the net to give the Mystics a 57-56 lead, stunning the Liberty with only 10.8 seconds left in what had already been a gritty tug-of-war between the Women's National Basketball Association rivals.

Her 10th and final basket, the most defining one of her young pro career, provided the last points of the game. And with it, Holdsclaw helped Washington (4-2) exact its second straight victory over the Liberty (3-5) this season and give the Mystics their fifth victory in six meetings since Holdsclaw became the league's No. 1 draft pick last year.

''This is probably the biggest shot I have hit on the professional level and it feels great,'' Holdsclaw said, still beaming after scoring a game-high 23 points in front of 11,559 fan, 70 of them representing friends and family of the Astoria, Queens, native.

Until Holdsclaw got the ball on a designed inbounds play with 16.4 seconds left, the Liberty looked as though it would preserve a 56-55 lead. But Holdsclaw's shot created the seventh lead change of the game, and it was a dagger.
''I'd rather lose by 50 points than by one point,'' Liberty guard Becky Hammon said.

Hammon missed a layup with 5 seconds left, and her teammate Tari Phillips took a baseline shot with 1.6 seconds left that fell short. Vickie Johnson could not turn the rebound into a shot fast enough and when the buzzer sounded, Holdsclaw punctuated the air with her index finger.
A star at Christ the King High School, Holdsclaw first played in the Garden as a willowy senior at Tennessee and was struck with stage fright, scoring 8 points.
''I never had a great game at the Garden, '' she said after making 10 of 21 shots and collecting 12 rebounds. ''But tonight, for once in my career, I came in and felt relaxed.''
Sue Wicks saw that.
''She's finally being the superstar she was touted to be,'' Wicks said. ''It was a tough shot and she nailed it.''
Wicks threw a hand in Holdsclaw's face when Johnson, who was guarding Holdsclaw, was screened out by Washington's Vicky Bullett. Johnson threw a hand up, too. No matter.
''Huge. Huge. Huge,'' Washington Coach Nancy Darsch said, describing Holdsclaw's game-winning basket. ''She can get over people and get her own shot.''

Holdsclaw was the only Mystics player who scored in double figures and her final shot spoiled an inspired games by the Liberty's Teresa Weatherspoon, who scored a season-high 14 points, and Johnson, who also scored 14.

Johnson made two foul shots with 1:28 remaining, and then the Liberty forced a steal from its stifling full-court press. Hammon, who had 10 first-half points to help give the Liberty a 29-26 advantage, calmly sank a 3-pointer at the top of the arc with 1:16 left. With 51.4 seconds remaining, Weatherspoon stretched for a loose ball, and caused it to go off a Mystics player. After a timeout, Johnson made a running layup for the 56-55 lead by the Liberty that Holdsclaw wiped out.
Earlier in the second half, Holdsclaw had brought her team back from a 9-point deficit and had converted the 3-point play that gave Washington its first second-half lead, 45-43, at the 9:40 mark.
Holdsclaw's heroics would not have been so necessary if the Liberty had not gone scoreless for five minutes in the middle of the second half.
''Sometimes I think we want to beat them too bad, we missed easy shots,'' Johnson said.
Holdsclaw did not.
WOMEN'S BASKETBALL
